sections.intro:
{{Cinematic}} {{Moonraker}} {{Infobox film | image = Moonraker (HD Poster).jpg | caption = ''Moonraker'' theatrical poster | bond = [[Roger Moore]] | writer = [[Ian Fleming]] (novel) | screenplay = [[Christopher Wood]] | director = [[Lewis Gilbert]] | producer = [[Albert R. Broccoli]] | editing = [[John Glen]] | music = [[John Barry]] | song = "[[Moonraker (song)|Moonraker]]" | distributor = United Artists | released = [[007_Timeline#1979|26 June 1979]] ([[United Kingdom|UK]]) | runtime = 126 minutes | budget = $34 million | gross = $210.3 million | preceded_by = ''[[The Spy Who Loved Me (film)]]'' | followed_by = ''[[For Your Eyes Only (film)]]''|composer=John Barry (Composer)
[[Hal David]] (Lyrics)|performer=[[Shirley Bassey]]}} {{Quote|What do you know about Moonraker?|[[M (Bernard Lee)|M]] and [[James Bond (Roger Moore)|James Bond]]|Moonraker}} '''''Moonraker''''' is a 1979 spy film, and the eleventh film in the [[James Bond]] film series as well as the fourth starring [[Roger Moore]] as Bond. It it also the final film to have [[Bernard Lee]] as M two years before his death in 1981. This film was released in 1979. The film was produced by [[Albert R. Broccoli]] and [[Michael G. Wilson]]. The film owes very little to [[Moonraker (novel)|Ian Fleming's novel of the same name]], although it does feature its character [[Sir Hugo Drax]]. The screenplay was written by [[Christopher Wood (writer)|Christopher Wood]], who had previously co-written and novelised the screenplay for the previous film, ''[[The Spy Who Loved Me]]''; both ''Moonraker'' and ''The Spy Who Loved Me'' share the main plot element of a billionaire industrialist attempting to wipe out humanity and start a great reset of civilisation while sheltering in an isolated location. Wood also novelised ''Moonraker'' in 1979. The title comes from "moonraker", a synonym for moonsail, the highest sail carried by sailing ships. It also refers to reaching for the moon, which runs parallels with the film's main aspect of travelling into space. Despite being the most commercially successful Bond film up to that point (only being eventually surpassed by [[GoldenEye (film)|''GoldenEye'']], 16 years later) reviews of Moonraker were mixed - with critics citing its outlandish and over-the-top plot which veered into space opera.
sections.Plot Summary:
{{More Images Needed}}
===Africa===
The movie begins with a space shuttle being stolen while being transported on the top of an airliner. It blasts right off the aeroplane, incinerating the crew.

Bond is returning from [[South Africa]] on a different plane when [[Apollo Air Hostess|the hostess]] and [[Apollo Pilot|pilot]] betray him. He doesn't know it yet, but on the plane with him is the villain [[Jaws (Richard Kiel)|Jaws]], who had appeared in the last Bond film, ''[[The Spy Who Loved Me (film)|The Spy Who Loved Me]]''. The pilot shoots the planes controls intending for Bond to crash along with the plane after parachuting to safety. Bond wrestles with the pilot, eventually pushing him out of the airplane still wearing the parachute. Bond jumps after him and manages to strip the pilot of the parachute and puts it on. Jaws, having jumped out of the plane after Bond, attempts to remove Bonds parachute then bite him on the neck. Bond resists long enough to deploy his 'chute. Jaws parachute fails to deploy and he lands in the middle of a circus tent.

===California===
When he gets to [[London]], Bond is ordered to investigate Drax, who is a supplier of space shuttles to the US government in the film. Bond goes to see Drax at [[The Drax Estate|his ''château'']] in California, which has been shipped stone by stone from [[France]]. While there, Drax and Bond go hunting, and [[Tree Assassin|a man set up in a tree]] to kill Bond is shot by 007. At first Drax thinks Bond was shooting at the game bird and thinks he missed. Bond says 'look again, Mr. Drax' and it is seen that the man in the tree was shot. 

At Drax's research facility Bond meets [[Holly Goodhead (Lois Chiles)|Dr. Goodhead]] who sets him up in a machine which simulates G forces, although one of Drax's men tries to kill him by making it spin too fast.

===Venice===
[[File:Moonraker-14.jpg|thumb|Bond battling Chang in the Venetian clocktower.]]
Bond photographs some of the plans at Drax's lab with a miniature camera, which lead him to a glass manufacturer in [[Venice]], [[Italy]]. While there, he is attacked by Drax's henchman [[Chang]], and they proceed to smash up most of a glass display area before Bond ultimately throws him out the window of a clock tower, causing him to crash through a piano in the plaza below. There is also a chase through the canals, where Bond's [[Gondola Hovercraft|gondola]] has an engine, and even turns itself into a hovercraft, going across plazas in Venice. Bond also meets Dr. Goodhead in Venice, and discovers she is a [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] agent. Bond sneaks into Drax's research facility, discovering [[Nerve Gas|highly toxic gases]], and calls in [[M (Bernard Lee)|M]] from London, although when they go back to the research facility they are surprised to see that it has completely changed and Drax is there to meet them. However after the meeting, while the [[Fredrick Gray|Minister of Defense]] wants Bond taken off the assignment, Bond shows M one of the vials he swiped earlier confirming to him the laboratory was real, and M discreetly allows Bond to continue his investigation under the pretense of being on leave.

===Brazil===
Bond is led to Rio de Janeiro where he meets Dr. Goodhead and Jaws again, and Bond battles it out with Jaws on top of a cable car high above the city, ending in Jaws' cable car crashing into the house at the end. Bond and Dr. Goodhead are captured by agents of Drax posing as ambulance drivers and taken away in an ambulance, where they are able to escape, knocking [[Ambulanceman|one of the men]] out the door and into a British Airways advertising sign.

Bond then travels up the Amazon river looking for Drax's research facility, which houses his fleet of [[Moonraker (Space Shuttle)|Moonraker]] shuttles, and has to deal with Jaws and some other of Drax's men following him. Bond's boat has a number of gadgets, including mines and torpedoes, and Bond drives over a waterfall and ejects with a hang-glider just in time, while Jaws's boat plummets below. 

As Bond makes his way through the jungle, [[Blonde Beauty|a girl]] in the distance catches his eye and puts him in a trance. Bond follows a girl inside [[Amazonian Launch Complex|the temple]] and encounters [[Drax's Girls|other girls]]. Bond fails to notice that the rock he stands on tilts him into the pond, and along comes a reticulated python. Bond struggles to reach the edge of the pond but the snake catches him and tries to overpower him. Bond uses a hypodermic pen to kill the snake. 

As Bond reaches the edge of the pond, Jaws stands in front of him and is captured again after killing the snake, which was Drax's pet, and, alongside Dr. Goodhead, is put in the bay of a space shuttle, which is about to launch so that the shuttle will incinerate them on take off. Fortunately Bond's watch has plastic explosive attached to it, and they manage to escape just in time, and posing as pilots, board one of Drax's shuttles into orbit.

===Outer Space===
Drax has converted a toxin found in [[Orchidae Nigra|a species of orchid]] found in the Amazon River basin, which in its natural state causes sterility, into a lethal nerve agent. He plans to destroy all human life (the toxin affects only humans) by launching a series of 50 globes containing the toxin from a [[Drax's Space Station|space station]]; the toxin would be dispersed when each globe broke up during reentry into [[Earth]]'s atmosphere. Before launching the globes, Drax transported several hundred carefully selected young men and women to the space station. They would live there until Earth was safe again for human life; these people would be the seed for a "new master race". Bond reaches the villain's orbital lair by means of the space shuttle. Holly Goodhead, is a CIA agent who competently wards off villains and pilots the space shuttle.

The space station managed to stay hidden from radar on earth due to a radar jamming device, which Bond and Goodhead must disable. After they do this, radar spots them from Earth and there is a brief phone conversation between the Americans and the Russian [[General Gogol]] before the Americans send marines on board a space shuttle for Drax's station. When they arrive, a battle with lasers ensues. At the end of the film, Jaws who had opposed Bond throughout, ends up going to his side when Bond points out that Jaws' [[Dolly|girlfriend]] would not live up to Drax's standards for human 'perfection'. Jaws also speaks for the first time, saying to his girlfriend, "Well, here's to us." As they break open a champagne bottle on their way back to Earth. Bond and Goodhead leave on a space shuttle to destroy the three probes which are heading towards earth. Bond destroys the first two on automatic pilot and finally gets the last one on manual control. At the end of the film the Americans and British try to talk to Bond and Goodhead to congratulate them, but they are having sex under a sheet while in orbit. M rhetorically asks 'what does bond think he's doing' and [[Q (Desmond Llewelyn)|Q]], who is looking at the radar screen, but not at the picture of the two of them says 'I think he's attempting re-entry sir'.

sections.Production:
[[File:Moonraker (Pan, 1961).jpg|thumb|right|200px|Cover of the 1961 Pan Books release of Moonraker. The movie deviates significantly from the original novel's plot.]]
In 1955, the film rights to ''Moonraker'' novel were initially sold to the Rank Organisation for £10,000. Fleming eventually bought back the rights in 1959, with the Rank Organisation ultimately never doing anything with it.

In the end credits of the previous Bond film ''[[The Spy Who Loved Me]],'' it says "James Bond will return in ''[[For Your Eyes Only]]''". However, after the tremendous box office success of [[w:c:starwars:Star Wars: Episode IV A New Hope|''Star Wars'' (i.e. "A New Hope")]] and ''[[Wikipedia:Close Encounters of the Third Kind|Close Encounters of the Third Kind]]'' in 1977, the producers decided they wanted to cash in on the subsequent science fiction craze and make Moonraker instead, thus For Your Eyes Only was held back to become the next Bond film after Moonraker.

The title was taken from [[Ian Fleming]]'s third James Bond novel, [[Moonraker (novel)|Moonraker]]. Though ultimately the plot of the film is broadly disassociated with the original novel, with only really the main villain's name kept and both involving rocket/missile technology (in the book, "Moonraker" was a [[Moonraker Rocket|tactical ballistic missile]] and the movie, its a [[Moonraker (Space Shuttle)|series of Space Shuttles]]). Instead, the film is closer to the prior ''The Spy Who Loved Me'' in plot construction, seeing the return of Jaws as a major henchman. If anything, most of the aspects of the original book would later be utilized in 1995's ''[[GoldenEye (film)|GoldenEye]]'' and 2002's ''[[Die Another Day (film)|Die Another Day]]'' -- both starring [[Pierce Brosnan]] as James Bond.

===Script===
[[Tom Mankiewicz]] had written a screenplay of ''Moonraker'' that was eventually discarded. Some scenes from his script were later used in subsequent films, including the [[Bede BD-5J|Acrostar Jet]] sequence used in the teaser for ''[[Octopussy (film)|Octopussy]]'', and the Eiffel Tower scene in ''[[A View to a Kill]]''. Also, Nepal and India were considered for filming locations - the latter of which was used in Octopussy.

===Cast===
[[Lois Chiles]] had been first approached by the producers for the role of [[Anya Amasova]] in ''[[The Spy Who Loved Me]]'' but had turned down the role as she had planned to leave the acting profession at that time. She later shared an airline seat with director Lewis Gilbert during her brief retirement where she ended up in the film.

Bernard Lee makes his final appearance as 'M'. The actor was in ill health at the time of filming. Although he was scheduled to appear in the next Bond film, he died during pre-production.

===Location scouting===
Cubby Broccoli took a holiday in Brazil where he visited Iguacu Falls - the location used in the film for the boat chase (the actual boat chase was filmed outside Jupiter, Florida doubling for the Amazon).

===Product placement===
Drax's vehicle fleet seen at his French chateau (the real life Vaux-Le-Vicomte) consisted of American Motors and Jeep vehicles (from an AMC Concord, Jeep CJ-7, Jeep J10 light truck, and a Jeep Cherokee) - at the time of the film's release, American Motors and Jeep products were distributed in Europe by Renault since March 1978 (the French automaker previously collaborated with AMC during the mid-1960s when Renault assembled Ramblers in Europe and its Argentine subsidiary produced a version of the Rambler American as the IKA (later Renault) Torino. 

Renault would become the owner of AMC in the early 1980s until 1987 when financial affairs in France would lead to a divestment when its shares of AMC were sold to the Chrysler Corporation - Jeep (which became part of AMC back in 1970 after its previous owners Willys-Overland and Kaiser owned the brand) became a Chrysler division with Chrysler, Dodge, and Ram. AMC previously had a product placement in [[The Man with the Golden Gun (film)|''The Man with the Golden Gun'']].

===Effects===
The title sequence is dominated by the recurring image of the moon, with silhouettes of women floating weightlessly across the screen. Maurice Binder achieved this effect by having the women jump on a trampoline during filming. According to [[Albert R. Broccoli]], the title sequence for this film alone cost more to produce than the entire first feature film in the series, ''[[Dr. No (film)|Dr. No]]''.

sections.Equipment:
===Gadgets===
{{main|List of Gadgets}}
====Used by Bond====
{| border="0" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="1" class="article-table article-table-selected" style="width: 100%; "
|style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;"|[[File:Gadgets_-_MR_-_Dart_Gun.png|100px]]
|style="background-color:transparent;"|'''[[Wrist-Mounted Dart Gun]]''' - Worn like a wrist-watch, the weapon is activated by nerve impulses from the user's wrist. It can fire both armor-piercing and cyanide-coated darts; the former Bond uses to escape from a centrifuge and the latter to kill Hugo Drax.
|-
|style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;"|[[File:Gadgets_-_MR_-_Safe_Cracker.png|100px]]
|style="background-color:transparent;"|'''[[Safe-Cracking Device]]''' - A safe-cracking device that is concealed within a normal looking cigarette case. It uses X-Ray technology to see the inner workings of the safe's locking mechanism. Bond uses it to break into the safe in Drax's office.
|-
|style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;"|[[File:Miniature camera (Moonraker).png|100px]]
|style="background-color:transparent;"|'''[[Subminiature Camera]]''' - A miniature camera imprinted with Bond's 00 number (with the lens of the camera making up the middle 0 of the number). Bond uses it to take pictures of the plans inside Drax’s safe.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;border-color:transparent;"|[[File:Gadgets_-_MR_-_Watch.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;border-color:transparent;"|'''[[Explosive Wristwatch]]''' - A modified Seiko caliber M354-5019 wristwatch. It contains a small circular reel of explosive inside a rear compartment. Once placed, the explosives and fuse are linked to the watch by a small length of wire. The wristwatch itself acts as the detonator. Bond uses it to escape from the flame pit of Moonraker 5.
|}
====Used by others====
{| border="0" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="1" class="article-table article-table-selected" style="width: 100%; "
|style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;"|[[File:Gadgets_-_MR_-_Bolas.png|100px]]
|style="background-color:transparent;"|'''[[Exploding Bolas]]''' - Seen in testing at the MI6 monastery. Designed to entrap an object, such as a human, and explode when the bola balls hit each other.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;"|[[File:Gadgets_-_MR_-_Sleeping_Man.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;"|'''[[Sleeping Man Turret]]''' - An experimental weapon being developed by Q Branch. A machine gun turret disguised as a sleeping man. When activated the two halves of the man's "body" snap apart to reveal a turret inside.
|-
|style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;"|[[File:Gadgets_-_MR_-_Needle.png|100px]]
|style="background-color:transparent;"|'''[[Poison Pen]]''' - CIA Agent Holly Goodhead carries a number of gadgets of her own, including a pen with a retractable poison needle. Activated by clicking the top of the pen.
|-
|style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;"|[[File:Gadgets_-_MR_-_Daily_Diary.png|100px]]
|style="background-color:transparent;"|'''[[Diary Dart Gun]]''' - A one-shot miniature dart gun concealed in the spine of a seemingly normal diary. Activated by pressure on the book's spine. One of the four CIA gadgets belonging to Dr. Holly Goodhead.
|-
|style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;"|[[File:Gadgets_-_MR_-_Perfume.png|100px]]
|style="background-color:transparent;"|'''[[Perfume Flame Thrower]]''' - A bottle of Christian Dior perfume which doubles as a miniature flame thrower. This was one of Holly Goodhead's CIA gadgets and, incidentally, a product placement for Christian Dior perfume.
|-
|style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;"|[[File:Gadgets_-_MR_-_Handbag.png|100px]]
|style="background-color:transparent;"|'''[[Purse Transmitter]]''' - A radio transmitter disguised as a purse. The device's antenna is retractable and extends from the purse when in use. Standard CIA field equipment belonging to Dr. Goodhead.
|}

===Weapons===
====Firearms====
{| border="0" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="1" class="article-table article-table-selected" style="width: 100%; "
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Unknown - Infobox.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''Smith & Wesson Model 38 Bodyguard''' - used by the [[Apollo pilot]] during the pre-titles jet plane sequence to shoot and destroy the plane's controls.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:M1911_BondWiki1A.JPG|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[M1911 Pistol]]''' - seen in hands of one of Drax's men during the motorboat chase in Brazil.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Unknown - Infobox.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''Holland & Holland Royal''' - hunting shotguns used at Drax's Estate during the hunt. One is used by Drax, with Bond using one to shoot Drax's sniper assassin off a tree.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:MP40 Bondwiki1.jpg|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[MP-40]]'''  - used by the assassins during Venice boat chase.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Mac-10.jpg|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[MAC-10]] Submachine Gun''' - used by Jaws and some of Drax's sentries during the Brazil river chase.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:M16A1 Bondwiki1.jpg|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[M16 Rifle]]''' - carried by Drax's security at the [[Amazonian Launch Complex]].
|-
|}
Curiously, Moonraker is the only time in a movie before 1999's ''[[The World Is Not Enough]]'' when EON/cinematic James Bond is seen without his signature [[Walther PPK]]. Although there exist promotional material in which Bond is seen with it, he is never seen brandishing it during the film at any point.

====Other weapons====
{| border="0" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="1" class="article-table article-table-selected" style="width: 100%; "
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Unknown - Infobox.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''Knives''' - used by the Funeral Boat assassin.
|-
|style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;"|[[File:Gadgets_-_MR_-_Laser.png|100px]]
|style="background-color:transparent;"|'''[[Moonraker Laser Rifle|Laser Rifle]]''' - A laser rifle that can be used in space. A version of this gun is shown being tested to somewhat gruesome effect on a wax dummy during Bond's visit to the MI6 monastery. The rifle is also used in the ''[[GoldenEye video games|GoldenEye]]'' video games and ''[[007 Legends]]''.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Black orchid toxin (Moonraker).png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''X-52 [[Nerve Gas]]''' - deadly nerve gas synthesized from the [[Orchidae Nigra]], which is fatal only to human beings. Its central to Hugo Drax's plan, who, from his space station, aims to drop them on earth via satellite globes to exterminate mankind, so that his chosen ones may repopulate the earth afterwards.
|-
|}
sections.Gadgets:
{{main|List of Gadgets}}
====Used by Bond====
{| border="0" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="1" class="article-table article-table-selected" style="width: 100%; "
|style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;"|[[File:Gadgets_-_MR_-_Dart_Gun.png|100px]]
|style="background-color:transparent;"|'''[[Wrist-Mounted Dart Gun]]''' - Worn like a wrist-watch, the weapon is activated by nerve impulses from the user's wrist. It can fire both armor-piercing and cyanide-coated darts; the former Bond uses to escape from a centrifuge and the latter to kill Hugo Drax.
|-
|style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;"|[[File:Gadgets_-_MR_-_Safe_Cracker.png|100px]]
|style="background-color:transparent;"|'''[[Safe-Cracking Device]]''' - A safe-cracking device that is concealed within a normal looking cigarette case. It uses X-Ray technology to see the inner workings of the safe's locking mechanism. Bond uses it to break into the safe in Drax's office.
|-
|style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;"|[[File:Miniature camera (Moonraker).png|100px]]
|style="background-color:transparent;"|'''[[Subminiature Camera]]''' - A miniature camera imprinted with Bond's 00 number (with the lens of the camera making up the middle 0 of the number). Bond uses it to take pictures of the plans inside Drax’s safe.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;border-color:transparent;"|[[File:Gadgets_-_MR_-_Watch.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;border-color:transparent;"|'''[[Explosive Wristwatch]]''' - A modified Seiko caliber M354-5019 wristwatch. It contains a small circular reel of explosive inside a rear compartment. Once placed, the explosives and fuse are linked to the watch by a small length of wire. The wristwatch itself acts as the detonator. Bond uses it to escape from the flame pit of Moonraker 5.
|}
====Used by others====
{| border="0" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="1" class="article-table article-table-selected" style="width: 100%; "
|style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;"|[[File:Gadgets_-_MR_-_Bolas.png|100px]]
|style="background-color:transparent;"|'''[[Exploding Bolas]]''' - Seen in testing at the MI6 monastery. Designed to entrap an object, such as a human, and explode when the bola balls hit each other.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;"|[[File:Gadgets_-_MR_-_Sleeping_Man.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;"|'''[[Sleeping Man Turret]]''' - An experimental weapon being developed by Q Branch. A machine gun turret disguised as a sleeping man. When activated the two halves of the man's "body" snap apart to reveal a turret inside.
|-
|style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;"|[[File:Gadgets_-_MR_-_Needle.png|100px]]
|style="background-color:transparent;"|'''[[Poison Pen]]''' - CIA Agent Holly Goodhead carries a number of gadgets of her own, including a pen with a retractable poison needle. Activated by clicking the top of the pen.
|-
|style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;"|[[File:Gadgets_-_MR_-_Daily_Diary.png|100px]]
|style="background-color:transparent;"|'''[[Diary Dart Gun]]''' - A one-shot miniature dart gun concealed in the spine of a seemingly normal diary. Activated by pressure on the book's spine. One of the four CIA gadgets belonging to Dr. Holly Goodhead.
|-
|style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;"|[[File:Gadgets_-_MR_-_Perfume.png|100px]]
|style="background-color:transparent;"|'''[[Perfume Flame Thrower]]''' - A bottle of Christian Dior perfume which doubles as a miniature flame thrower. This was one of Holly Goodhead's CIA gadgets and, incidentally, a product placement for Christian Dior perfume.
|-
|style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;"|[[File:Gadgets_-_MR_-_Handbag.png|100px]]
|style="background-color:transparent;"|'''[[Purse Transmitter]]''' - A radio transmitter disguised as a purse. The device's antenna is retractable and extends from the purse when in use. Standard CIA field equipment belonging to Dr. Goodhead.
|}

sections.Vehicles:
{{main|List of James Bond vehicles}}
===Major vehicles===
{| border="0" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="1" class="article-table article-table-selected" style="width: 100%; "
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Vehicle_-_Rolls-Royce_Silver_Wraith II.png]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[Rolls-Royce Silver Shadow I LWB]]''' - When Bond arrives in Rio de Janeiro, he is seen as a passenger in a blue Silver Wraith II which takes him to his hotel.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Vehicle - Moonraker Chevy Ambulance.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''Ambulance (1974 Chevrolet C-10)''' - Ambulance used by Drax's men to abduct Bond and Goodhead in Brazil.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Vehicle - Moonraker J12 Cabriolet.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''1936 Hispano-Suiza J12 Cabriolet ''' - the car that brings Bond to Drax's hunting game.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Vehicle - Moonraker Lincoln Continental.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''1978 Lincoln Continental Executive Limousine'''
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Vehicle - MP Lafter.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''1979 MP Lafer'''
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Vehicle - HD DE4.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''Harley-Davidson DE 4''' - the cart that Drax travels around his estate with.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Vehicle - Moonraker Film Mini Moke.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[Austin Mini Moke]]'''
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Vehicle - Moonraker Film Transportation Vehicle Amazon Base.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''Made for Movie transportation vehicle'''
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Vehicle - 206JetRanger Moonraker.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[Bell 206 JetRanger]]''' - one is piloted by [[Corinne Dufour|Corrine]] to bring Bond to Drax's Estate in California.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Vehicle_-_Handley_Page_Jetstream.png]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[Handley Page Jetstream|Handley Page HP.137 Jetstream 1]]''' - In the pre-titles sequence, Bond is almost left stranded on this aircraft with no pilot and no instruments, until he is pushed out with no parachute by Jaws.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Unknown - Infobox.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''Boeing 747-123 Shuttle Carrier Aircraft''' - the plane that carries one of the Moonraker shuttles in the pre-title sequence. Its destroyed when Drax's infiltrators activate the shuttle to fly off to Drax's base.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Unknown - Infobox.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''Aérospatiale-BAC Concorde 101''' (Air France) - Bond arrives to Rio de Janeiro in this. 
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Unknown - Infobox.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''Lockheed L-188A Electra''' (Drax Air Freight) - freight plane that Bond and Goodhead spot in Brazil.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Vehicle_-_Gondola.png]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[Gondola Hovercraft]]''' – while attacked on the canals of [[Venice]], Bond escapes his assailants by using his gondola's hidden self-propulsion system which also included a hovercraft function to leave the water.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Vehicle - Moonraker Funeral Boat.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''Funeral Boat'''
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Vehicle - Moonraker Villain Venice Speedboat.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''Custom-built Speedboat''' - used by the two Venice assassins after the Funeral Boat assassins fail at their plan.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Vehicle_-_Glastron_Boat.png]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[Glastron Carlson CV23HT|Q's Hydrofoil Boat]]''' (modified '''Glastron Carlson CV23HT''') – Bond uses this boat to escape from Jaws while searching for the spacecraft launching facility. Comes with all the usual Q refinements such as tracking torpedoes and a hang-glider when an immediate ditching of the boat was required.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Vehicle - Moonraker Villain Glastron SVV-189.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[Glastron SSV-189]]''' - used by Drax's sentries during the Amazon river chase.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Vehicle_-_Moonraker_Shuttle.png]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[Moonraker (Space Shuttle)|Moonraker Shuttle]]''' - "Moonraker" is a brand name applied to a space shuttle orbiter design, built by Drax Industries for NASA. Though the actual Space Shuttle had not flown by the time ''Moonraker'' was released, the Drax Moonraker is identical in design. These were named Moonraker 1-6.
|}

sections.Reception and legacy:
Moonraker remains one of the better known James Bond movies, yet it bears a complicated legacy. Its a divisive film, with some considering it the low point in the Bond franchise for its over-the-top sci-fi elements, while others appreciate it for its spectacle and camp value. While not universally loved, Moonraker has secured a unique place in the Bond canon, especially for fans who appreciate its unashamed embrace of late-'70s sci-fi and spectacle.

It got mixed-to-negative reception from the film critics when it was first released. A lot of them thought the movie focused too much on action and visual effects rather than the spy elements. The space setting was seen as gimmick trying to ride the success of Star Wars. Some pointed out the film had too many gadgets, and the tone became more/too silly and funny. The story was considered mostly perfunctory, with some deeming it wasn’t as strong as in earlier Bond films. [[Roger Moore]]'s acting was mostly considered aptly charming, though some felt that he was starting to look too much like a comic-book character.

Financially, the film was a big box office success when it was first released. Earning over $210 million globally, it made Moonraker the highest-grossing Bond film up to that point in franchise's history (even though its higher budget decreased the true profit margin). Its believed that Moonraker helped ensure that the franchise stayed financially successful.

===Effect on Bond franchise===
[[File:Aztec Goldeneye 007.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Screenshot of the "Aztec" bonus mission in ''GoldenEye 007'', which is a tribute to the 1979 movie.]]
Effectively, Moonraker is a film that pushed Bond to his limits (literally into space) and helped define the boundaries of what the movie audiences and series fans wanted from the 007 franchise. EON would address criticism pointed towards the film, with the next film - 1981's ''[[For Your Eyes Only]]'' - serving as kind of course correction and returning Bond to a more grounded and serious tone.

Although mostly ignored within EON's own film canon - with exception to few nods in ''[[Die Another Day]]'' - Moonraker is more acknowledged in the extended James Bond franchise. One of the better known tributes being the [[List_of_Levels_of_GoldenEye_007_(1997)#Aztec|"Aztec"]] bonus mission in the famous [[GoldenEye 007 (1997 game)|GoldenEye 007]], which is based on the Aztec Launch Complex from the movie.

Additionally, the plot of the videogame [[James Bond 007: NightFire]] appears to use the 1979 Moonraker movie as the template for its plot. Like in the Moonraker movie, James Bond goes to outer space in NightFire.

===Staff opinion===
[[Roger Moore]] saw Moonraker as fun but far-fetched. He was self-aware and good-humored about its excesses, even if he thought it strayed a bit too far from classic Bond. Moore would famously compare the 2002 Bond movie ''[[Die Another Day (film)|Die Another Day]]'' with ''Moonraker'' unfavorably, by saying that the former “went too far” even for “the first Bond in space”.

Screenwriter [[Christopher Wood]] would later profess that he bears the blame for turning the film too jokey and without serious stakes. Though he also deemed that the outdated nature of the original Moonraker novel was not helpful in writing. Ultimately, what he cherished the most was being able to work with Lewis Gilbert.

[[Albert R. Broccoli]] deemed that capitalizing on the science‑fiction boom triggered by ''Star Wars'' was a sound decision, but was displeased with the budget ballooning during the filming, stating that “I once made entire movies for less than the phone bills on this one.”

[[Richard Maibaum]] commented and criticized: "With ''Moonraker'', we went too far in the outlandish. The audience did not believe any more and Roger spoofed too much. Thank God I didn’t write that one.” ''Moonraker'' was the third and final Bond screenplay that Maibaum didn't write or cowrite, in his lifetime. The other two being ''You Only Live Twice'' and ''Live and Let Die.''

===Influence===
The film inspires part of the plot of ''[[Wikipedia:Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow|Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow]]''.

In a scene in the ''Buffy the Vampire Slayer'' episode [[w:c:buffy:Life Serial|Life Serial]] when the Nerd Trio are arguing over who the better James Bond actor is, Warren expresses dislike for Moonraker twice because of the gondola scene, calling it "inexcusable".

sections.Trivia:
===Easter Eggs===
As the first truly science fictional Bond film, ''Moonraker'' pays homage to two sci-fi classics:
* When Bond arrives at Drax's pheasant shoot, a man plays the first three notes of "Also sprach Zarathustra", the famous theme from ''2001: A Space Odyssey'' on a bugle. 
* Later, when Bond observes a Drax scientist entering an access code into a keypad, the tones heard coming from the keypad form the famous five-note "alien message" theme from ''Close Encounters of the Third Kind''. 
* In another film reference, the song "Nobody Does it Better" - the theme from the previous Bond film ''The Spy Who Loved Me'' - is also reprised on the soundtrack when Bond arrives at Drax's mansion in California.

===Miscellaneous===
*The Jaws character (played by [[Richard Kiel]]) makes a return, although in ''Moonraker'' the role is played more for laughs than as the killing machine that he was in ''[[The Spy Who Loved Me]].'' (See [[Jaws]] for more information on the character changes.)
*Executive Producer [[Michael G. Wilson]] continues a tradition in the Bond films he started in the film ''[[Goldfinger]]'' where he has a small cameo role. He appears twice in ''Moonraker'', firstly as a tourist outside the Venini Glass shop in Venice, then at the end of the film as a technician in the NASA control room.
*''Moonraker'' was at one point considered to be the Bond film to follow ''[[On Her Majesty's Secret Service]]''
*In 2004, reports surfaced of a rumoured, lost 1956 version of ''Moonraker'' by [[Orson Welles]]. Supposedly, this lost film recently was discovered as 40 minutes of raw footage with Dirk Bogarde as Bond, Welles as Drax, and [[Peter Lorre]] as Drax's henchman. However, the film soon was revealed as an April Fool's Day joke. [http://www.commanderbond.net/Public/Stories/2323-1.shtml See here for more information.]
*Moonraker was the third of the three Bond films for which the theme song was performed by Shirley Bassey.
*It is to date the only James Bond film where Bond ventures into outer space, especially during its climax.
*The film marks the first time Bond's superiors (including [[M (Bernard Lee)|M]]) cross paths with the primary villain. During an investigation in [[Drax Industries|Drax's Venice laboratory]], Bond, along with M and the [[Frederick Gray|Minister of Defence]], are confusingly shocked to discover the main laboratory has been converted into a lavish dining room with Drax himself receiving them. The visibly humiliated officials plan to discharge Bond from the mission, but M seemingly changes his mind after the 007 agent hands him one of the toxin's vial to be analyzed. M would never come face to face with any of Bond's main opponents following this scene until 1987's ''[[The Living Daylights (film)|The Living Daylights]]'' (where [[General Koskov]] exaggeratedly slanders [[Leonid Pushkin]], the new head of KGB, as the mastermind behind the killings of British and American agents during a [[Blayden House|debriefing with MI6 officials]] including [[M (Robert Brown)|M]] and the Minister of Defence), 1999's ''[[The World Is Not Enough (film)|The World Is Not Enough]]'' (where [[M (Judi Dench) (classic film continuity)|Judi Dench's M]] is kidnapped by [[Elektra King]]), 2012's ''[[Skyfall (film)|Skyfall]]'' (where [[Raoul Silva]] has a lengthy private vendetta against [[M (Judi Dench) (modern continuity)|M]] and the British Intelligence as a whole) and 2015's ''[[Spectre (film)|Spectre]]'' (where [[M (Ralph Fiennes)|Ralph Fiennes' M]] apprehends [[Blofeld (Christoph Waltz)|Ernst Stavro Blofeld]] after being defeated and cornered by Bond following a lengthy boat-and-helicopter chase on the Thames).
*The fact the Moonraker shuttles were based upon the design of the real-life NASA shuttle was not a coincidence. At the time of the film's production, the first space shuttle was intended to launch in 1979. However, this launch ended up being cancelled and the first shuttle did not fly until 1981, making ''Moonraker'' lose some of its timeliness.
